physical_barriers.formula: Physical barriers include skin, mucous membranes, and cilia that prevent pathogen entry
physical_barriers.correct: Intact skin provides a waterproof keratinised barrier; mucus traps pathogens; cilia sweep mucus away

wrong.answer: Physical barriers kill pathogens directly
wrong.error: Confusing physical barriers with chemical or cellular defences
wrong.fix: Physical barriers prevent entry but don't kill pathogens - that's the role of chemical barriers and immune cells
wrong.action: Physical = block/trap; Chemical = kill/inhibit

wrong.answer: Skin is a chemical barrier
wrong.fix: Skin is primarily a physical barrier (keratin, tight junctions); it has some chemical components (sebum, low pH)
wrong.action: Skin is physical first, with chemical components adding protection

wrong.answer: Mucus is produced by cilia
wrong.error: Confusing the roles of goblet cells and cilia
wrong.fix: Goblet cells produce mucus; cilia are hair-like projections that move the mucus
wrong.action: Goblet cells = mucus production; Cilia = mucus movement

persistent.action: List physical barriers: skin (keratinised), mucous membranes (trap), cilia (sweep), tight junctions (seal)

chemical_barriers.formula: Chemical barriers include antimicrobial substances like lysozyme, stomach acid, and sebum
chemical_barriers.correct: Lysozyme breaks down bacterial cell walls; stomach acid denatures pathogens; sebum lowers skin pH

wrong.answer: Lysozyme works by lowering pH
wrong.fix: Lysozyme is an enzyme that breaks peptidoglycan bonds in bacterial cell walls; acid works by denaturing proteins
wrong.action: Lysozyme = enzyme action; Acid = denaturation

wrong.answer: Chemical barriers only work outside the body
wrong.fix: Chemical barriers work both externally (skin) and internally (stomach acid, vaginal pH)
wrong.action: Chemical barriers exist at all body surfaces including internal passages

wrong.answer: Sebum is a physical barrier
wrong.fix: Sebum is a chemical barrier - its fatty acids lower skin pH and inhibit microbial growth
wrong.action: Sebum = oily secretion with antimicrobial fatty acids = chemical barrier

persistent.action: Review: lysozyme (enzyme), acid (denature), sebum (low pH), defensins (pore-forming)

microbiota_barrier.formula: Normal flora compete with pathogens for nutrients and space, preventing colonisation
microbiota_barrier.correct: Commensal bacteria produce antimicrobial substances and maintain conditions unfavourable to pathogens

wrong.answer: Normal flora are harmful bacteria that must be eliminated
wrong.fix: Normal flora are beneficial microorganisms that protect against pathogens through competition
wrong.action: Commensal = beneficial; Pathogen = harmful

wrong.answer: Antibiotic use strengthens the microbiota barrier
wrong.error: Not understanding antibiotic effects on normal flora
wrong.fix: Antibiotics kill normal flora too, disrupting the microbiota barrier and allowing pathogen overgrowth
wrong.action: Antibiotics can cause opportunistic infections by disrupting normal flora

wrong.answer: Normal flora only exist in the gut
wrong.fix: Normal flora colonise skin, respiratory tract, urogenital tract, and gut
wrong.action: Microbiota exist at all body surfaces that contact the external environment

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of microbiota protective role
persistent.action: Study how commensals protect: competition for nutrients, space, production of antimicrobial compounds

skin_structure.formula: The epidermis contains keratinised dead cells while dermis contains blood vessels and immune cells
skin_structure.correct: Keratinocytes produce keratin as they move outward and die; Langerhans cells in epidermis detect pathogens

wrong.answer: Living cells form the outer skin layer
wrong.fix: The outer epidermis consists of dead, keratinised cells; living cells are in deeper layers
wrong.action: Outer layer = dead keratinised cells = physical barrier

wrong.answer: Blood vessels reach the skin surface
wrong.fix: Blood vessels are in the dermis; the epidermis is avascular and relies on diffusion
wrong.action: Epidermis = no blood vessels; Dermis = vascularised

wrong.answer: Skin contains no immune cells
wrong.fix: Langerhans cells (dendritic cells) in the epidermis sample antigens and activate immunity
wrong.action: Langerhans cells = skin's early warning system for immune activation

persistent.gap: Confusion about skin structure and immune components
persistent.action: Draw skin layers: epidermis (dead keratinised + Langerhans) → dermis (blood vessels, immune cells)

respiratory_barriers.formula: Respiratory barriers include mucus, cilia, and nasal hairs that trap and expel inhaled pathogens
respiratory_barriers.correct: The mucociliary escalator moves mucus and trapped particles up toward the throat for swallowing or expulsion

wrong.answer: Cilia push particles deeper into the lungs
wrong.fix: Cilia beat in coordinated waves to move mucus UP and OUT of the respiratory tract
wrong.action: Cilia move mucus toward throat = mucociliary escalator

wrong.answer: The alveoli are lined with cilia
wrong.fix: Alveoli have thin walls for gas exchange; cilia line the bronchi and trachea, not alveoli
wrong.action: Cilia in airways; thin epithelium in alveoli for gas exchange

wrong.answer: Sneezing is a chemical barrier
wrong.fix: Sneezing and coughing are physical/mechanical responses that expel pathogens
wrong.action: Reflexes (sneeze, cough) = physical expulsion mechanisms

persistent.action: Trace pathway: nasal hairs → mucus → cilia → mucociliary escalator → throat → swallowed/expelled

digestive_barriers.formula: Digestive barriers include stomach acid, bile, enzymes, and gut microbiota
digestive_barriers.correct: Stomach pH of 1-2 kills most ingested pathogens; bile has antimicrobial properties; gut flora compete with pathogens

wrong.answer: Stomach acid has a neutral pH
wrong.fix: Stomach acid has a very low pH (1-2), which is highly acidic and lethal to most pathogens
wrong.action: Gastric acid pH 1-2 = highly acidic = kills most pathogens

wrong.answer: Digestive enzymes only digest food
wrong.error: Not recognising antimicrobial role of enzymes
wrong.fix: Digestive enzymes also break down pathogen structures, providing antimicrobial protection
wrong.action: Enzymes break down both food and pathogen components

wrong.answer: Peristalsis has no barrier function
wrong.fix: Peristalsis moves material through the gut, preventing pathogen accumulation and colonisation
wrong.action: Peristalsis = mechanical clearance = physical barrier function

persistent.gap: Incomplete understanding of digestive defence layers
persistent.action: List digestive barriers: acid (pH 1-2), bile, enzymes, peristalsis, gut microbiota

urogenital_barriers.formula: Urogenital barriers include urine flow, low vaginal pH, and mucosal secretions
urogenital_barriers.correct: Regular urination flushes pathogens; vaginal lactobacilli produce lactic acid maintaining low pH

wrong.answer: Urine kills pathogens through antibodies
wrong.error: Attributing adaptive immune function to urine
wrong.fix: Urine's antimicrobial effect is mainly physical flushing, plus low pH and some antimicrobial peptides
wrong.action: Urine = flushing action + low pH; not adaptive immunity

wrong.answer: The vagina has an alkaline pH
wrong.fix: Healthy vaginal pH is acidic (3.5-4.5) due to lactobacillus-produced lactic acid
wrong.action: Vaginal pH ~4 = acidic = inhibits pathogen growth

wrong.answer: Urogenital tract lacks normal flora
wrong.fix: The urogenital tract has normal flora, especially lactobacilli in the vagina that maintain acidity
wrong.action: Lactobacilli = beneficial vaginal flora = maintain low pH

persistent.action: Review: flushing (urine), low pH (vaginal lactobacilli), mucus, antimicrobial secretions

plant_barriers.formula: Plants have physical barriers (cell walls, bark, cuticle) and chemical defences (phytoalexins, toxins)
plant_barriers.correct: Cellulose cell walls and waxy cuticle prevent entry; phytoalexins are antimicrobial compounds produced in response to infection

wrong.answer: Plants have immune cells like animals
wrong.error: Applying animal immune concepts to plants
wrong.fix: Plants lack mobile immune cells; they rely on cell-based recognition and chemical defences
wrong.action: Plants = no immune cells; each cell can mount defence responses

wrong.answer: Plant defences are all constitutive
wrong.fix: Plants have both constitutive (always present) and induced (activated by infection) defences
wrong.action: Constitutive = cuticle, cell wall; Induced = phytoalexins, PR proteins

wrong.answer: The cuticle is a chemical barrier
wrong.fix: The cuticle is primarily a physical barrier (waxy coating) that prevents water loss and pathogen entry
wrong.action: Cuticle = waxy physical barrier on leaf surfaces

persistent.action: Compare: Physical (cell wall, cuticle, bark) vs Chemical (phytoalexins, tannins, PR proteins)
